p.s: In the following, I will discuss whether The Merchant of Venice fuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes or raises awareness for the problems of antisemitism.
Throughout the play, Shylock is always characterized by him being a jewJew.
The other characters call him the Jew, combine insults with his religion or talk about his Jewish heart.
This is antisemeticanti-semeticand fuels such stereotypes because it engraves Shylock being Jewish as something bad or, at least, something which sets him apart from everyone else.
It does not raise awareness against antisemitism as it is not commented by any characters but is continuously present in the whole play.
Moreover, Shylock has some typical Jewish stereotypes: he works in the financial business and is portrayed as very mean about money.
This can be seen in the given excerpt as Shylock does not mainly grieve his daughter's eloping but rather the financial loss he suffers in this.
This does not raise awareness against antisemitism because Shylock is just being portrayed that way.
One has to be conscious about those stereotypes to recognize them and therefore this promotes antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes as they are unconsciously entered into the play.
By not seeing them as stereotypes, the audience inherits this way of thinking.
Furthermore, Shylock takes the role of the villain in this play.
Him being a Jew is always taken into account in the play when other characters talk badly about him which furthermore deepens the antisemeticanti-semetic view against Jews.
As his religion does not define his bad actions in the play, it would not matter if Shylock had another religion but he is being treated differently in the play.
Once again, this promotes antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes as the villain is a Jew in this play and that is put into the foreground when talking about Shylock.
Nonetheless his actions which would, from the audience's perspective make him the villain have nothing to do with religion but only with money, revenge and hate.
This cannot raise awareness against antisemitism as no character changes the perception about Shylock and therefore he is only describes as the Jewish villain.
Some argue that Shylock is only that hateful and revenge-seeking as he is in this excerpt because he has experienced so much hate and antisemitism in his life.
He wants to take revenge on Antonio because he hates him for always having bullied him and Shylock having suffered under Antonio's but also the other characters' antisemitism his whole life.
This raises awareness for antisemitism because it shows how hard Shylock has suffered under his treatment and that he is rather a victim than a villain.
It portrays the extent of the hate he has experienced and its effect on him.

This cannot be an argument for promoting antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes because it shows Shylock as a victim of antisemitism and a stereotype would be that he is bad because he is a Jew and therefore experiencing antisemitism but it is the other way around.
Lastly, in Elizabethan times being Jewish was different than today.
Shakespeare had probably never seen a Jew his whole life as the religion had not spread far around the world and in deeply Christian England one would not find many Jews.
Therefore, he wrote his play based off stereotypes he had heard, stories of other people and just the society's standards back then.
This indicates that the play promotes antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes as even the writer wrote it off mainly such sources.
How could he raise awareness for the problem of antisemitism if he neither knew a Jew nor had ever seen society's antisemeticanti-semetic treatment of Jews?
Not at all.
Weighing up, throughout the whole play antisemeticanti-semetic values and stereotypes are being pictured.
Shylock is being shown as the bad Jew, the villain, everyone hates him due to his religion and he is experiencing antisemeticanti-semetic hate.

I don't think that the argument of Shylock being a victim due to antisemitism is strong enough to invalidate the others because for that one needs to realize that he is a victim and this does not appear in the first reading but only analysis.
The strongest argument, in my opinion, is that Shakespeare presumably wrote this play off antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes - so how should the play not promote those stereotypes?

Concludingly, The Merchant of Venice in my opinion fuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes because just reading it is not enough to understand the problem of antisemitism here, for raising awareness one needs to analyse tha play to see the problematic structures.
